In this method, DNA/RNA sequence is represented and characterised by a two-step process: representation of the sequences using graphs and characterisation of the graphs by graph invariants. A graph invariant is a graph-theoretic property which is preserved by isomorphic graph (Harary 1969; Janežič et al. 2007). A graph 𝐺 is defined as an ordered pair consisting of two sets, 𝑉 and 𝐺=( 𝑉( 𝐺), 𝑅), where 𝑉( 𝐺) represents a finite nonempty set of points and 𝑅 is a binary relation defined on the set 𝑉( 𝐺). The elements of 𝑉 are called vertices, and the elements of 𝑅 also symbolised by 𝐸( 𝐺) or 𝐸 are called edges. Such an abstract graph is commonly visualised by representing elements of 𝑉( 𝐺) as points and by connecting each pair ( 𝑢, 𝑣) of elements of 𝑉( 𝐺) with a line or edge if and only if ( 𝑢, 𝑣) ϵ R. The vertex, 𝑣, and edge, 𝑒, are incident with each other, as are 𝑢 and 𝑒. Two vertices in 𝐺 are called adjacent if ( 𝑢, 𝑣) ϵ R, i.e. they are connected by an edge. A walk of a graph is a sequence beginning and ending with vertices in which vertices and edges alternate and each edge is incident with vertices immediately preceding and following it.
